journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Non-linear parametric vibrations of a composite column under uniform compression

article-meta.aff: Department of Applied Mechanics, Lublin University of Technology, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Jerzy Warmiński, Department of Applied Mechanics, Lublin University of Technology, Nadbystrzycka 36, 20-618 Lublin, Poland. Email: j.warminski@pollub.pl

article-meta.issue-title: Includes a special section on Parametric Excitation: Applications in science and engineering

abstract.p: Parametric oscillations of a prismatic, thin-walled composite column with a channel section are considered in the article. The simply supported column is made of a seven-layer composite with a symmetric ply alignment. The non-linear problem of buckling is solved with Koiter’s asymptotic theory within the first-order approximation by adoption of a plate model. The asymptotic approximation leads to non-linear equations allowing evaluation of the two mode buckling effect. Parametric vibrations, produced by a periodically changing load component, are investigated near the principal parametric resonances. The approximate analytical solutions are determined by the multiple time scales of method. The influence of amplitude and frequency of parametric excitation on the structure response is investigated. An example bifurcation scenario and a possible transition to chaotic oscillations are also presented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The development of composite materials leads to new designs of thin-walled structures which, in contrast to their small weight, may carry very large loads. Modern composite materials, i.e. laminates, have been very widely used. A better understanding of phenomena that occur under loads is necessary to correctly evaluate the performance of composite thin-walled structures. The strength of composites along the direction of the reinforcing fibre alignment is several times higher than along other directions. The mechanics of composite structures has been presented in many books and papers, for example.1,2 Static interactive buckling of composite column has been described, among others, in papers.3–5 However, if the load is not constant, but it includes variable components, then the strength of the structure may essentially decrease. Detailed reviews of problems of dynamic buckling under impact are presented in monographs.6–8 The monograph9 deals with the experimental aspects of dynamic buckling. The dynamic response of thin-walled structures, subjected to in-plane non-periodic loading, for example a pulse load, is considered there. In that case dynamic buckling can be treated as an amplification of initial displacements, or stresses. For the dynamic buckling of a perfect structure, due to pulse loading, there is no exact counterpart in the static bifurcation load. Therefore, dynamic bucking can be defined as the dynamic response of a structure which attains unacceptable level of displacements or stresses.

The interactive dynamic buckling of thin-walled structures subjected to in-plane load has been investigated in reference,10 while the dynamic critical stresses have been evaluated in reference11 Papers12,13 and chapters of monographs7–9 deal with the response of structures subjected to oscillating loads, leading to, so-called, vibration buckling. The periodically changing load produces periodically changing coefficients in the mathematical model. Then, in certain frequency intervals, the trivial solution loses its stability and a parametric resonance occurs. In such a case, transverse vibrations become unacceptably large at critical combinations of amplitude, load frequency and damping. The most essential and dangerous, from the practical point of view, is the principal parametric resonance. This phenomenon appears for sufficiently small values of the axial force, when the loading frequency equals twice the natural bending frequency of the system (the column in our case). Apart from the principal case fundamental resonances may also appear, when the loading frequency coincides with the natural bending frequency of the column. Moreover, the secondary parametric resonances may also occur. So, vibration buckling corresponds to the buckling resulting from parametric excitations. Detailed review of problems of vibration of axially loaded structures has been presented in references.7–9,14

The asymptotic theory of stability of thin-walled structures of the first-order non-linear approximation15–19 allows simultaneous evaluation of the effect of imperfections and interactions of different buckling modes on system behaviour. Solutions, for a static load, based on the asymptotic method have been determined in references.4,20–23

In this article, the authors deal with aspects of the dynamic behaviour of thin-walled composite column under a load composed of static and periodic parts. The mathematical model of the structure considers geometrical non-linear terms which couple considered global and local buckling modes of the column. The dynamic response is investigated around the principal parametric resonances.

sec.title: The problem formulation
sec.p:
A thin-walled composite C-bar subjected to compression is considered as the object of this study. The column under analysis is built of rectangular plates of length L and constant thickness h (Figure 1(a)). The plates are connected along longitudinal edges and simply supported at both ends. To each plate, a local Cartesian system of coordinates has been assigned (Figure 1(b)). The constitutive equations of the material of all the plates are assumed to be linear according to Hooke’s law. Applying the classical theory of composite plates1,2 and the plate model of a thin-walled structure,3 the following geometrical relationships for the main strains are formulated for each single plate3,5 (1) where u, v and w are the components of the displacement vector with respect to the axes x, y and z with the same assumed thickness of all the plates. Figure 1.
Channel column and its dimensions and local coordinate system.
The indices separated by the comma denote the partial derivatives with respect to the coordinate system.

Employing the classical theory of multi-layer plates (Appendix 1), the constitutive equations have the following form1,3 (2) where N1, N2 and N3 are the dimensionless forces, whereas M1, M2 and M3 are the dimensionless moments (3) and Eo is the reference Young’s modulus.
From the principle of virtual work for a single plate, taking into consideration relationships (1), the following equilibrium equations are satisfied (4)
More detailed analysis is presented in Appendix 1.

The solution to system (4) for the single plate that forms a thin-walled column has to fulfill the kinematic and static conditions along the longitudinal edges and, additionally, the boundary conditions corresponding to simple supports on both the column ends. A detailed analysis is given in reference.3 Such formulated non-linear problem of stability based on the second-order non-linear approximation has been solved for the static case by the asymptotic method of Byskov–Hutchinson.16 The displacements U and the forces N are expanded into the power series with respect to the dimensionless amplitudes of the buckling mode ξp (5) where U(0) and N(0) are the pre-buckling fields, U(p) and N(p) the critical states and U(pq) and N(pq) the post-buckling fields. The range of indices is equal to [1, n], where n is the number of interacting buckling modes. The rule of summation after repeating indices has been assumed.
Finally, in the static case, the interaction of n eigenmodes leads to a non-linear system of equations3,5,16,17 (6)

To derive differential equations of motion for the dynamic case, the second kind of Lagrange’s equations have been applied. Apart from the potential energy, the kinetic energy of the structure has also been included, resulting in ordinary differential equations with inertia terms10,11,23 (7) where ζr is the dimensionless amplitude of the rth buckling mode (maximum deflection referred to the thickness of the first plate), σr, ωor and ζr * the critical stress, frequency of free transverse vibrations corresponding to the rth buckling mode when the compression stress is equal to 0, dimensionless amplitude of the initial deflection corresponding to the rth buckling mode, respectively; bpqr are the non-linear coefficients of the first-order approximation and cpqsr are the non-linear coefficients of the second-order approximations.
Accepting the simplification that imperfections are equalled 0 (i.e. ζr * = 0) and adopting the theory of the first-order non-linear approximation, equation (7) can be written as follows (8)

The definitions for expressions for the bpqr coefficients are determined in Appendix 2.3 In equations (7) and (8), the inertia forces of the pre-buckling state have been neglected.23,24 The static problem of interactive buckling of thin-walled multilayer columns (equation (6)) has been solved by the method presented in reference,3 while the frequencies of free vibrations have been determined in reference.24 The main limitation of the adopted theory is the assumption of a linear dependence between the curvatures and second-order derivatives of the displacement w (i.e. κx=-w,xx, κy=-w,yy and κxy=-w,xy).25,26 More detailed analysis is presented in Appendix 2.
Considering the interaction of the global buckling mode and the lowest local one, r = 2, and p, q = 2, equation (8) takes the form (9)
Introducing dimensionless time (10) which is expressed with respect to the second natural frequency, and then introducing it to the time-derivative definitions (11) (12) finally, we get (13) or (14)

Now, we assume that compressive stress (denote as σ(τ)) of the column is composed of constant and periodic components. Therefore, the stress due to external load is written as (15) where qo represents the static component and q and Ω the amplitude and frequency of the periodic part of the load, respectively.
Substituting (15) into (14) we get (16) or (17)

Introducing dimensionless natural frequencies Ω01=ωo1/ωo2 and Ω02=ωo2/ωo2=1, equation (17) is written in the form (18) where ζ·1(τ)≡ζ1,τ, ζ·2(τ)≡ζ2,τ, ζ··1(τ)≡ζ1,ττ, and ζ··2(τ)≡ζ2,ττ denote the first- and the second-order time derivatives.

Frequency Ω02 is introduced formally to have consistency in notation. Parameter δ=σ2/σ1 means the ratio of critical stresses σ1; σ2; ρ0 represents a dimensionless constant load and ρ the amplitude of parametric excitation, defined as: ρ0=q0/σ2, ρ=q/σ2. Parameter Ω represents a dimensionless parametric excitation frequency.
The load imposed to the structure is below the critical value if (19)
In equation (18), b12=b121+b211, b21=b212+b122 and furthermore modal viscous damping is introduced, by means of coefficients β1 and β2.

sec.title: Dynamics of the composite column around the principal parametric resonances––analytical solutions
sec.p:
The set of equations (18) constitutes a non-linear two-degree-of-freedom system which includes non-linear quadratic terms and parametric excitation. Moreover, the equations are coupled by means of both coordinates. This implies that both modes are coupled and that they can interact.27,28 To find solutions of such non-linear coupled problem, we assumed those non-linear coupling terms are small. Analysing the values of the coefficients, presented in Table 2, we see that this assumption is in fact true for real structures. Also in the further analysis, we assume that the natural frequencies Ω01 and Ω02 are incommensurable. This means that a case of internal resonance is excluded. Table 1.
Frequency of free vibration ωor and critical stresses σr for global buckling mode (i.e. r = 1) and the lowest local mode (i.e. r = 2).
ωo1 (rad/s) ωo2 (rad/s) σ1 (MPa) σ2 (MPa)
1098.50 1796.22 49.518 14.711
Table 2.
Values of non-linear coefficients bpqr of the first-order approximation.
b111 b221 b12 = b121 + b211 b112 b222 b21 = b212 + b122
−0.0126409 −0.0563475 0.0273859 0.00520127 −0.00306516 −0.0428073

Assuming that the non-linear terms, the parametric excitation and the damping are all small, we express all those coefficients in equation (18) by a formal small parameter ɛ
Thus, recalling that Ω02=1, the differential equations of motion take the form (20)
If the parameter ɛ is equal to zero, then equations (20) are uncoupled. That situation corresponds to a linear system.
Let us assume that ɛ is small and positive, which means that the system is weakly non-linear.

Due to the parametric excitation term, we may expect the appearance of parametric resonances.29 In this article, we deal with the principal (2:1) parametric resonances around the first Ω01 and the second Ω02 natural frequencies. However, we have to bear in mind that the fundamental (1:1) and the secondary parametric resonances may exist, as well. Furthermore, for the non-linear system internal and combination resonances also may appear. In this article, excluding the internal resonance, we investigate solutions near the principal parametric resonances. These resonances are the most dangerous and the most important from the practical point of view. 30–32

To determine approximate analytical solutions, we use the multiple time scale method.33 A solution of equation (20) is sought near the main parametric resonances in form of a series of the small parameter ε (21) coordinates ζj0(T0,T1), ζj1(T0,T1) are, respectively, the zeroth and first-order functions of time. Dimensionless time is also expressed by a series for the small parameter (22) where T0 and T1 are, respectively, the fast and slow time scales. Such time definitions results in the following formulae for the first- and the second-order time derivatives33 (23) (24) where Dn m=∂m/∂Tn means m-order partial derivative with respect to the nth time-scale.

As assumed earlier, we seek solutions near the natural frequencies for the principal parametric resonances. Then, the frequency of excitation is about 2 : 1 with respect to the natural frequency. The response of the column is subharmonic, according to the parametric excitation frequency Ω.

sec.title: Case 1. Principal parametric resonance for ΩΩ01≈2
sec.p: Assuming that Ω≈2Ω01, we can write (25) where ν1 is a frequency detuning parameter.

Substituting solution (21) into (20), taking into account the derivative definitions (23), (24), and expressing the natural frequency according to (25), after grouping terms with respect to order ɛ, we get a set of differential equations in the successive perturbation order
ɛ0––order (26)
ɛ1––order (27)
ɛ2––order (28)

Because, we excluded the internal resonance near the first natural frequency Ω01, the coordinate ζ1 plays dominant role. Therefore, the response of the second coordinate ζ2 may be taken into the solution in ɛ1, and the higher perturbation orders. Therefore, we may write the solution of equation (26) in the form (29) where i=-1 is the imaginary unit, A1 the complex amplitude and A¯1 its complex conjugate. Solution (29) is substituted into (27) and after grouping the terms in proper exponential functions, we get (30) where cc mean complex conjugate functions to those written in the equation and ST represent terms which generate secular terms in the solution of (30). Therefore, to avoid this situation, the ST have to be zero, thus we have (31)
Next, rejecting the ST terms, we may determine the particular solutions of equation (30) (32)
Substituting solutions (32) into the second-order equations (28) we get (33) (34)
To avoid secular terms in the solution of equation (33), we require vanishing secular generating terms, thus (35) where NST denotes non-secular generating terms.
Applying the so called reconstitution method, we may formulate the modulation equations for the complex amplitudes A1. The amplitude derivative with respect to dimensionless time takes the form (36)
Derivatives D1A1 and D2A1 are found from equations (31) and (35), thus we have (37)
Expressing complex amplitude A1 in the polar form (38) and then separating the real and imaginary parts of (37), we get the modulation equations for amplitude a1 and phase ϕ1 (39)
In steady state a·1=0, φ·1=0. Thus, equalling equations (39) to zero (40) (41) we can find the resonance curve around the principal parametric resonance (42)
We note that all the parameters in (41) and (42) have their original definitions, and are written without the tilde.

From the above equation, we can determine the amplitude a1 of the coordinate ζ1 as a function of a selected bifurcation parameter. Varying parameter Ω, we can find the resonance curve of the principal parametric resonance near the first natural frequency Ω01.
The phase angle φ1 can be found from (40), (41), by determining the sine and cosine functions and then dividing them out. After this transformation we get (43)

Taking into account the particular solutions (29), (32) and expressing the complex amplitudes in the polar form (38), according to (21), we obtain approximate solutions for the first- and second-coordinate (44)
Amplitude a1 and phase ϕ1 have to be found from the modulation equations (39), or in the steady state from (42) and (43).

sec.title: Case 2. The principal parametric resonance for ΩΩ02≈2
sec.p: The principal parametric resonance may also appear around the second natural frequency.

Assuming now that Ω≈2Ω02=2, we can write (45) where ν2 is a frequency detuning parameter around the second natural frequency. In this case, the second coordinate dominates, therefore we seek solution in the form (46)

Repeating a similar procedure as in Case 1, we get a set of equations in the ɛ0, ɛ1, ɛ2 perturbation orders. Solving, them successively, and eliminating the secular generating terms, we get solutions for both coordinates (47)
The secular generating terms lead to modulation equations for complex amplitude A2 obtained after reconstitution (48)
Expressing complex amplitude A2 by the polar form (49)
and then separating the real and imaginary parts, we get the modulation equations for amplitude a2 and phase ϕ2 (50)
Taking into account the steady state, we get the resonance curve of the principal parametric resonance for the second natural frequency after rearrangements (51)
All parameters in equation (51) are written in their original notation, without the tilde.

sec.title: Example calculations and numerical studies
sec.p: A detailed analysis of the calculations is conducted for compressed columns with the following dimensions for the channel cross-sections (Figure 1): b1 = b3 = 50 mm, b2 = 25 mm and h = 0.92 mm. The length of the column is L = 450 mm. The column is made of a seven-layer composite with symmetric ply alignment [07]. Each layer of the thickness hlay = 0.131 mm is characterized by the following mechanical properties: Young’s elastic moduli in the 1 and 2 material directions E1 = 130 GPa, E2 = 6.36 GPa, Kirchhoff’s modulus (shear modulus) in the 1, 2 plane G12 = 4.18 GPa, Poisson’s ratio in the 1, 2 plane ν12 = 0.32 and the density is 2000 kg/m3.

The static problem of interactive buckling of thin-walled multilayer columns represented by equation (6) has been solved by the method presented in reference,3 the frequencies of free vibrations have been analogously determined as in reference.24 Table 1 presents values for the frequency of free vibration ωor and critical stresses σr (r = 1,2) for global and the lowest local buckling modes. The values of the non-linear coefficients bijr of the first-order approximation are given in Table 2 and are calculated on the basis of reference.3 Modal damping of the structure has been assumed to be arbitrary with coefficients β1=0.01 and β2=0.01.

At first, let us consider solutions for the first-order perturbation near the first natural frequency. Taking into account equation (31) and, expressing complex amplitude A1 by the polar form (38), we get modulations equations in the first-order perturbation (52)

From the above, we determine the relation between the parameters which has to be satisfied to get periodic oscillations (53) where ν1 means the detuning parameter. From this equation, we can find the stability zones as functions of amplitude of parametric excitation ρ versus parametric frequency Ω (54)
In a similar way, we may find the stability zone near the second natural frequency (55)

Example curves for the data given in Tables 1 and 2, and three different static loads and damping coefficients are presented in Figures 2 and 3. Figure 2 presents stability zones corresponding to the first natural frequency Ω01≈0.612, while Figure 3 shows stability zones related to the second natural frequency Ω02=1. Below the shaded regions, the trivial solution is stable and asymptotically tends to zero. Inside the shaded regions, the trivial solution is unstable and the solution bifurcates to another attractor. Figure 2.
Influence of static load: (a) ρ0=0, ρ0=0.2, ρ0=0.7; β1=0.01, and damping (b) β1=0 β1=0.01, β1=0.05; ρ0=0.2, on the stability zones near the first natural frequency. Figure 3.
Influence of static load: (a) ρ0=0, ρ0=0.2, ρ0=0.7; β2=0.01, and damping (b) β1=0 β1=0.01, β1=0.05; ρ0=0.2, on the stability zones near the second natural frequency.

As we may intuitively predict, the increase of the static load shifts the stability zones into lower values of frequency Ω, which is clearly visible in Figures 2(a) and 3(a). The instability zones have been determined for fixed value of damping β=0.01 and three selected values of static load, ρ0=0, ρ0=0.2 and ρ0=0.7. For the first natural frequency (Figure 2(a)), the instability zone has been moved from about Ω=1.22 (case without static load ρ0=0) to Ω=1.12 (static load ρ0=0.7). Respectively, for the second natural frequency, the unstable region has been moved from Ω≈2 (ρ0=0) to Ω≈1.4 (ρ0=0.7).

The increase of damping increases the critical value of the amplitude ρ. Figures 2(b) and 3(b) present the instability zones for fixed static load ρ0=0.2 and for three values of damping coefficients β1,β2 equal to 0, 0.01 and 0.05. As we see, the zones are shifted up for the first (Figure 2(b)) and the second (Figure 3(b)) principal parametric resonance.

Unfortunately, the first perturbation order does not allow the determination of the amplitudes as a function of frequency or another bifurcation parameter. To get these dependencies, we have to examine the modulation equations for the second-order terms.

Solving equations (42) and (51), we find amplitude a1 and a2, respectively. The resonance curves are determined as functions of parametric excitation frequency a1=a1(Ω), a2=a2(Ω) with the rest of the parameter values fixed as in Table 2. The resonance curves, calculated around the first (Figure 4(a)) and the second (Figure 4(b)) principal parametric resonance, exhibit the softening effect. The unstable branch is marked by a dashed line. Taking one fixed frequency, for example Ω=1.21 for the first and Ω=1.94 for the second resonance curve, we may perform a bifurcation analysis versus the amplitude of parametric excitation. Figure 5 presents the bifurcation scenario when frequency of excitation is fixed and the amplitude is varied. Investigating Figure 5(a) and (b), we see that for small values of ρ, the zero (trivial) solution is stable. But after reaching a certain threshold, the trivial solution becomes unstable and then, the system jumps to periodic oscillations, after the subcritical Hopf bifurcation. This phenomenon occurs for ρ=0.15 for the first resonance and, ρ=0.12 for the second resonance region. We may conclude that the second (local) mode, which corresponds to amplitude a2, loses its equilibrium position stability earlier then the first (global) mode, represented by a1. After the subcritical Hopf bifurcation, the system may jump from the equilibrium to periodic oscillation, or vice versa, as pointed out by arrows in Figure 5(a) and (b). However, depending on the vibration amplitudes which are related to the potential energy level, more complex dynamics can also be observed. Figure 4.
Resonance curve around: (a) the first and the second (b) natural frequencies, ρ0=0 and ρ=0.1. Figure 5.
Amplitude of the column versus amplitude of parametric excitation around: (a) the first natural frequency, ρ0=0, Ω=1.21 and (b) the second natural frequency, ρ0=0, Ω=1.94.

Let us consider the conservative system. It means, that in (18) inertia, damping and excitation are equal to zero. The non-linear elasticity forces have been determined for ζ1 coordinate, substituting ζ2=0 in (18)1, and for ζ2 coordinate, substituting ζ1=0 in (18)2. Then, the following formulations for the potential energies, corresponding to the first and the second mode, are obtained (56) (57)
Equations (56) and (57) represent cross-sections of the potential surface V(ζ1,ζ2) at point (0,0) in ζ1 and ζ2 directions.

Courses of the potential functions V1(ζ1) and V2(ζ2) are presented in Figure 6. Due to the non-linear terms, these functions include the potential ‘well’. For a low energy level, the solution stays inside this well. But if the energy level is increased, then the system may jump from the ‘well’ and escape to infinity. Figure 6.
Potential functions of a non-linear conservative system for selected values of a static load: (a) the first mode potential V1(ζ1), ζ2=0 and (b) the second mode potential V2(ζ2), ζ1=0.

To get this phenomenon, we perform direct numerical simulations of equation (18). The bifurcation diagrams near the first and the second principal parametric resonance are plotted. For a fixed amplitude of parametric excitation, ρ=0.1, frequency Ω is varied around the principal parametric resonance zones. The solutions are plotted for every excitation period, starting from the same initial conditions ζ1=0.1, ζ·1=0, ζ2=0.1 and ζ·2=0 and then rejecting the first 500 periods of the transient response. Bifurcation diagrams for the first and the second principal parametric resonances are presented in Figure 7(a) and (b), respectively. The solution is manifested by double lines what means that the response of the column is subharmonic with respect to the excitation frequency. The resonance regions visible on the bifurcation diagrams correspond to the resonance zones analytically obtained and presented in Figure 4(a) and (b). However, direct numerical simulations may show more complex dynamics of the system. Figure 7.
Bifurcation diagrams near the first principal resonance: (a) coordinate ζ1 and (b) coordinate ζ2, ρ=0.1.

The situation complicates while parameter ρ is increased. Let consider a fixed excitation frequency near the first principal resonance, Ω=1.22. Increasing the amplitude of parametric excitation ρ, we get the bifurcation diagram presented in Figure 8. About ρ=0.06, the Hopf bifurcation appears and the solution jumps from zero to subharmonic oscillations. This is in accordance with the analytical prediction. However, near ρ=0.25, a period doubling bifurcation occurs. A zoom of this region is presented in Figure 8(b). After a cascade of period doublings, the system bifurcates to more complex dynamics represented by the dark region. The numerically calculated maximal Lyapunov exponents reach a positive value which means that this solution is chaotic. A further increase of amplitude ρ, after crossing a certain threshold leads to the escape phenomenon and then the solution goes to infinity. This is the case of the escape from the potential well. Figure 8.
Bifurcation diagrams of coordinate ζ1 versus amplitude of parametric excitation ρ near the first principal resonance, Ω=1.22: (a) full diagram and (b) zoom near the period doubling bifurcation.

sec.title: Conclusions and final remarks
sec.p: The non-linear model of the parametrically excited thin-walled, composite column, taking into account the two modes response, is considered. The asymptotic theory of the first-order non-linear approximation allowed an evaluation of the effect of various buckling mode interactions on the behaviour of thin-walled structures.

On the basis of the approximate analytical solutions, the instability regions near the principal parametric resonances are determined. The resonance curves exhibit a softening effect. Trivial solutions go to periodic oscillations after the subcritical Hopf bifurcation. We may conclude that for the assumed configuration of the composite column, the second (local) mode loses stability of its equilibrium position earlier then the first (global) mode. Moreover, the dynamics of the structure is very sensitive to the initial conditions. The increase in the dynamic load amplitude leads to a period doubling bifurcation, and then the solution transits to chaotic oscillations after the cascade of period doublings.

We have to remember that the non-linear problem considered here requires a four-dimensional space analysis to get all the possible attractors, and to check all possible bifurcation behaviours. Detailed bifurcation scenarios and possible transition to chaotic dynamics will be investigated in a separate paper.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The research leading to these results has received funding from the European Union Seventh Framework Programme (FP7/2007-2013), FP7—REGPOT—2009—1, under grant agreement No: 245479. The support by the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education—grant no 1471-1/7.PR UE/2010/7—is also acknowledged.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr Pedro Ribeiro from the University of Porto for his help and constructive discussions.

WarminskiJ. Nonlinear normal modes of a self-excited system driven by parametric and external excitations. Nonlinear Dyn 2010; 61: 677–689.
WarminskiJ. Nonlinear normal modes of coupled self-excited oscillators in regular and chaotic vibration regimes. J Theor Appl Mech 2008; 46(3): 693–714.
WarminskiJKecikK. Instabilities in the main parametric resonance area of a mechanical system with a pendulum. J Sound Vib 2009; 332: 612–628.
NayfehAHPaiFP. Linear and nonlinear structural mechanics. New York, NY: John Wiley and Sons Inc., 2004.
NayfehAH. Nonlinear interactions, analytical, computational, and experimental methods. New York, NY: John Willey and Sons, Inc., 2000.
CartmellMP. Introduction to linear, parametric and nonlinear vibrations. London: Chapman and Hall, 1990.
NayfehA. Problems in perturbations. New York, NY: John Wiley and Sons, 1985.

sec.p:
Let us consider a single plate (Figure 9). Basic dimensions of the plate are length parallel to the x direction (denoted as L), width b (parallel to the y direction) and thickness h (parallel to the z direction). In this case, the Hamilton’s Principle can be written as follows3,15–19 (58) where Λ is a Lagrange’s function, K a kinetic energy, Π a total potential energy. Figure 9.
The plate structure.

The total potential energy is equal to (59) where p0(x), p0(y), τ0xy(x) and τ0xy(y) are pre-buckling in-plane load in the middle surface of the plate, q the transverse load, Ω = L × b × h = S × h a volume of the plate and u, v and w the components of the displacement in x, y and z directions, σx, σy, σz and εx, εy, εxz the stress and strain in x, y and z directions, respectively.
The kinetic energy for the plate is written as (60) with kinematic conditions (61)
The energy variation can be written as follows (62)

Let us consider the kth ply of the laminate.1,2 Using the classical thin plate theory, the strains of the kth ply can be related to the strains and curvatures of the middle surface of the laminate in the form1–3 (63)
The stress–strain relations can be written as follows (64) where [K] is the transformed reduced stiffness matrix.1–3

To determinate the resultant moments and forces acting on the laminate, the kth ply stresses are integrated through the ply thickness and the sum of the effects from all the plies is then taken.1–3 (65) (66)
Carrying out the integrations and then adding for all the layers yields the constitutive equations for the laminate as follows (67) where

In equation (67), the submatrix [A] related to the in-plane response of the laminate is called extensional stiffness. The submatrix [D] is associated with the out-of-plate bending response of the laminate and is called bending stiffness. The submatrix [B] is a measure of interaction between the membrane and the bending action. For a symmetrical structure of layers, the submatrix [B] is equal to zero.
The middle surface strains and curvatures are equal3–5,10–11 (68)
After calculations, the following system of equations has been obtained3 (69) (70) (71) for x = const (72) for y = const (73)
For the plate corner (x = const and y = const) (74)
Initial conditions for t = const (75) where (76)
Relations (69) constitute a set of equilibrium equations and (72) to (74) correspond to the boundary conditions.
In the static case, differential equations of equilibrium are as follows (77)

In the static case, the total potential energy variation can be written as follows3,19,20 (78) and the strain variation is equal to (79) where σ is a stress tensor, ε a strain tensor, U the displacements fields, L1 and L11 the operators.

For linear problem of buckling, it can be written as follows3,19,20 (80) where σ(0), ε(0) and U(0) are the pre-buckling fields, and σ(1), ε(1) and U(1) the buckling states, λkr critical value of the load parameter corresponding to U(1) and ξ the buckling mode amplitude.
In the buckling state, the expression for σ(1), ε(1) has the following form (81)
Equation (79) can be written as follows (82)
After placing (80) to equations (78) and (79), the following relation is received (83)
Because δU = U(1) thus (84)
For the post-buckling state, it can be written as follows3,19,20 (85) and (86)
Performing necessary calculations, the following equation has been obtained (87) or (88) where the coefficients are equal to (89)
If the imperfections are not equal to 0, equation (88) can be written as follows (90) where U¯ is imperfection.
If the imperfections are equal to (91) then equation (90) takes the form (92) where ξ* is the amplitude of the imperfection.
In the dynamic case, equation (78) has a form (93)
Assuming load as the time function (94) and (95) we get (96) where ωo1 is frequency corresponding to U(1).
For interactive buckling of n eigenmodes, it can be written as follows (97) and (98) where the coefficients are equal to (99)
Finally, in the dynamic case, the interaction of n eigenmodes leads to a non-linear system of equations10,11,23 (100)
Additionally, introducing the relation (101) where σ is a compressive stress corresponding to parameter λ and σr the critical stress, equation (100) can be written as follows (102)
